articles.title: ‘A good moment in time for us’: Firefox head on AI browsers and what’s next for the web
articles.summary: Firefox GM Anthony Enzor-DeMeo says AI-first browsers are early—paid AI ~3% globally, business models unclear. He’s tested Atlas, Comet, etc., and prefers answers with citations. He warns AI subscriptions could close the web. Firefox will add AI cautiously: fully optional, privacy-first, AI-agnostic sidebar (Copilot, Gemini, Perplexity); new Perplexity partnership, terms undisclosed. Users can refuse data storage, browse privately without login; less personalization by default. Generational splits: Gen Z favors personalization/choice; older cohorts lean privacy. On the Google trial, the judge preserved funding for independent browsers; AI–search monetization unresolved. Firefox still has ~200M users; neutrality amid launches (Atlas, Edge Copilot Mode, Comet, Chrome with Gemini) seen as growth.

articles.title: More than a million people every week show suicidal intent when chatting with ChatGPT, OpenAI estimates
articles.summary: OpenAI estimates over 1m ChatGPT users each week express potential suicidal planning, and 0.07% of weekly users (~560,000 of 800m) show possible psychosis or mania signs. It calls the figures preliminary and hard to detect. The disclosure comes amid a lawsuit over a teen’s suicide and an FTC probe into chatbot harms to youths. OpenAI says GPT-5 improved safety: 91% compliant vs 77% prior in >1,000 self-harm evaluations, with hotline surfacing and break reminders. It enlisted 170 clinicians who reviewed 1,800 responses and shaped guidance. Researchers warn about sycophancy; OpenAI downplays causality. CEO Sam Altman says mitigations allow easing content restrictions, including adult erotica.

articles.title: Amazon plans to cut 30,000 corporate jobs in response to pandemic overhiring
articles.summary: Amazon will cut up to 30,000 corporate jobs starting Tuesday, reversing pandemic overhiring and advancing CEO Andy Jassy's streamlining via AI-driven efficiencies. The reductions equal about 10% of its roughly 350,000 white-collar staff (1.55m total), the largest layoff in company history, per media reports; Amazon declined comment. Cuts span HR (People Experience and Technology) - potentially 15% - plus Devices and Services and Operations. Managers trained Monday to deliver email notices. Shares rose 1.2% ahead of earnings. Jassy is trimming bureaucracy and layers; an anonymous inefficiency line yielded 1,500 tips and 450 process changes. Peers Microsoft, Meta, Alphabet also downsized.

articles.title: Ultra-HD televisions not noticeably better for typical viewer, scientists say
articles.summary: Cambridge and Meta scientists, in Nature Communications, find typical living‑room distances erase visible gains from 4K/8K over 2K. Using a movable 27in 4K monitor, 18 participants detected 1‑pixel vertical lines to determine the eye’s limits: averages 94 pixels per degree (greyscale), 89 PPD (red/green), 53 PPD (yellow/violet). A text‑sharpness task with 12 participants matched these limits. Many common size–distance setups already exceed them; e.g., a 44in 4K TV at ~2.5m. A chart and free calculator map when extra pixels are wasted. 20/20’s 60 PPD benchmark underestimates typical acuity.

articles.title: Apple Watch Ultra 3 review: the biggest and best smartwatch for an iPhone
articles.summary: Apple Watch Ultra 3 refines Apple’s adventure smartwatch: bigger, brighter edge-visible screen in same 49mm titanium case (sapphire), S10 chip, new wrist‑flick and double‑tap gestures. Battery +6% delivers ~3+ days (11–14h high‑accuracy workouts); 0–50% in 30min. Adds satellite SOS (plus Find My; consumer messaging US/CA/MX) and stronger 5G/eSIM. Dual‑band GPS is among the most accurate; action button supports pre‑lock start; 100m water, 40m dive. watchOS 26 adds Waypoint face. Full health suite incl ECG, SpO2, sleep score, hypertension alerts; Workout Buddy AI coach (iPhone 15 Pro required). £749/$799. Best Apple Watch, modest upgrade; iPhone‑only, no third‑party faces, shorter life than Garmin Fenix.

articles.title: ‘People thought I was a communist doing this as a non-profit’: is Wikipedia’s Jimmy Wales the last decent tech baron?
articles.summary: Wikipedia turns 25. Jimmy Wales says his newborn’s 2000 health scare spurred a pivot from slow, expert-led Nupedia to an open wiki—now 7m English articles and 18 languages with 1m-plus each. His book, The Seven Rules of Trust, codifies purpose, good faith, neutrality and transparency; research shows politicization erodes trust. Pro-capitalist and president of Fandom, he rebuts Musk’s Wokipedia jibes and Grokipedia pitch, arguing AI is less a threat than authoritarian censorship; Wikipedia refuses cooperation and is blocked in China. He defends DEI grants amid 50m-of-177m claims as mission-critical outreach. Editors’ pandemic work modeled transparent misinformation control. He urges bolder UK governance.

articles.title: US and China reach ‘final deal’ on TikTok sale, treasury secretary says
articles.summary: US Treasury secretary Scott Bessent said Washington and Beijing have finalized a deal to transfer TikTok's US operations, to be consummated by Trump and Xi Jinping Thursday in Korea. The $14bn transaction gives US and international investors about 65% ownership, reduces ByteDance/Chinese stakes to under 20%, and puts the algorithm and six of seven board seats under the US-led group. Trump's Sept 25 order enabled the sale after delaying a 2025 ban. Potential investors include Rupert Murdoch and Larry Ellison; Barron Trump has been floated for the board. The accord sits within a broader trade framework covering farm purchases and fentanyl.

articles.title: Could the internet go offline? Inside the fragile system holding the modern world together
articles.summary: The piece maps a rare but plausible internet collapse: heavy concentration in hyperscale clouds (AWS, Google, Microsoft) creates systemic risks. A chain—tornado hits Google us-central1 (Council Bluffs), heatwave cripples AWS US-East-1 (Virginia), cyberattack on a European hub—forces reroutes that trigger an AI-introduced AWS bug post-layoffs, toppling Signal, Slack, Netflix, Lloyd’s and smart devices. Undersea cable cuts are routine; true doom targets core protocols: DNS/BIND or BGP. Downing Verisign would fell .com, stalling banks and hospitals (cf. 2016 Dyn). Experts Woźniak, Murdoch and Madory stress improbability yet fragility; niches (Mastodon, self-hosted, .io/.is, Siprnet) endure. A total shutdown might be hard to restart; UK ops once had a pub plan.

articles.title: Fare game: what the battle between taxis and Uber means for your airport trip in Sydney and Melbourne
articles.summary: To deter touts and compete with rideshare, Melbourne airport has begun a taxi fixed-fare booking trial at three Qantas domestic kiosks, issuing prepaid quotes and directing riders to Silver Service, Black and White, 13cabs or Silver Top. From 3 November, Sydney airport runs a 12‑month $60 flat fare to the CBD ($80 Maxi), with inspectors monitoring. Sydney’s Uber Pin kerbside pickup at the international terminal becomes permanent; Melbourne enabled kerbside Uber in 2021. Uber now dominates: Sydney international rose from 35% (2019) to 50% (2024), then 73% during the Pin trial (300,000 trips); taxis 27%. Melbourne: Uber ~60%, taxis ~20%. Sample fares: Melbourne taxi $78–79 vs Uber $57–65; Sydney taxi $60 vs Uber $45–66. NSW fines first overcharging to $3,000; Victoria proposes a two‑strikes ban.
